Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Studying and Supporting Productive Disciplinary Engagement in Demanding STEM Learning Environments across Cultures and Settings

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This early concept project seeks to build a partnership between two US universities who are currently creating learning environments to support engaged learning in STEM disciplines. This award will allow these researchers to begin a collaboration with Finnish researchers at Turku University. The collaborative partnership will allow the research team to collaboratively understand the nature of engagement in complex STEM learning environments to develop better methods for creating authentic learning systems across many settings and contexts.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises from how it informs our knowledge of how to retain and engage students in learning tasks. These types of environments extend across the learning spectrum from early years into college and also into the workforce. The international collaboration serves to expand the network and skills of students involved in the project. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers by helping the United States be globally competitive through international partnerships. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, Studying and Supporting Productive Disciplinary Engagement in Demanding STEM Learning, was part of a broader U.S-Finnish collaboration through the Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) Program. On the USA side, it featured an engineering educator from Oregon State University, Professor Milo Koretsky, and a Learning Scientist from the University of Washington, Professor Susan Nolen and their research teams. It was a partnership with Profs. Marja Vauras and Erno Lehtinen, from the University of Turku in Finland and Prof. Simone Volet from Murdoch University in Australia and their research teams.

The project focused on authentic learning environments to support engaged learning in science and engineering. We studied the innovative learning systems we have been developing where students take the role of practicing professionals (e.g., as an environmental scientist or a semiconductor process engineer) where they are encouraged to use the “language” and “practices” of the discipline to “get somewhere” (develop a product, improve a process, gain a better understanding of a phenomenon) over time. When students learn in environments that match the context in which they will do their professional work, they are more likely to be able to draw on what they have learned as professionals. Additionally, it has been shown that this type of learning environment helps retain students who might otherwise be at risk of leaving the science and engineering.

While we know a lot about how learning works in a classroom, the collaborative partnership allowed us to better uncover the nature of learning when students take on the role of professionals. While there has been some work done on this in isolated contexts, this project is the first time where these type of learning environments have been studied across levels and cultures. It also is the first time such a variety of environments have been studied using the same research methods so that meaningful comparisons can be more readily achieved.

We have been able to use these different contexts to uncover general understanding about how students and experts think and learn in these environments. We focus on doing and thinking. For example, several of the sites engage students in the role of designers. As designers they must make something (in some cases, virtually) to meet a need. This is doing. However, when they hit snags in their design, it forces them to think in very realistic ways of the profession. We examined this type of thinking in several contexts and found that while the background knowledge and the design projects were very different, we always saw the same three distinct ways of thinking. This type of thinking can be encouraged or obstructed by the design of the learning activity or by the moves of the teacher. Thus, with this understanding, we can intelligently design learning environments to better help our students learn and be more effective professionals. Second, we looked at the interactions of students when they worked on teams. Again, we saw certain ways students regulated their own and others behavior that were the same in different contexts. Teams that produced high quality work tended to have common ways to regulate their behaviors. With this knowledge we can help design learning activities to make more students effective in a team. This knowledge can be put into practice to enable production of more work-ready graduates.

This work has led to nine conference papers and two journal articles. Through this project several early career researchers were exposed to state-of-the-art learning systems and research methods across cultures.
